content: “What I believe wasn’t obvious then — and remains non-obvious now — was that tool adoption was not the real problem to solve.” I’m a little surprised at this statement as there’s really strong guidance in the agile manifesto: “Individuals and interactions over processes and tools”. There’s also a lot of lean / agile writing about avoiding over-dependence on tools. The mindset is critical. The agile transformation of my group at GE was driven top-down and was also heavily (though not wholly) tool-centric. I suspect that tool provision is an easy thing for senior managers to tick off and monitor. The tools are a great help in providing an easy pathway to useful practices, but unless there’s a significant extra push and spark from someone in terms ways of working on the ground, it’s risks being for nothing. That spark can come bottom-up or middle-management-out, but probably not top-down — it has to be *felt* locally. One area where I didn’t see the transformation succeed (I’ve left GE now) was in engineering’s relationship with the wider business. There wasn’t much agile or lean about that, sadly. Are there tools that can catalyse that? Thanks for the article.
